sections.title: What Are Alternative Investments?
sections.content: Alternative investments include assets beyond traditional stocks, bonds, and cash. Common alternatives include real estate, commodities, private equity, hedge funds, and cryptocurrencies. They often have low correlation with traditional markets and can provide diversification benefits.

points.title: Real Estate
points.description: Direct ownership, REITs, or real estate crowdfunding - provides income and inflation protection.

points.title: Commodities
points.description: Physical goods like gold, oil, or agricultural products - hedge against inflation.

points.title: Private Equity
points.description: Investing in private companies - potentially higher returns but illiquid and high minimums.

sections.title: Alternatives Are Not for Everyone
sections.content: Most individual investors should limit alternatives to 5-10% of their portfolio. They often have higher fees, less liquidity, and more complexity than traditional investments.

sections.title: Evaluating Alternative Investments
sections.content: Consider liquidity, fees, minimum investments, and your ability to understand and monitor the investment. Many alternatives require accredited investor status. Start small and understand the risks before allocating significant capital.

sections.title: Consider Alternatives Thoughtfully
steps: Assess whether alternatives fit your risk tolerance and investment goals
Research specific alternative investments and their historical performance
Start with liquid, low-cost alternatives like commodity ETFs or REITs
Monitor alternative investments closely and be prepared for illiquidity

sections.title: REITs for Real Estate Exposure
sections.content: Real Estate Investment Trusts (REITs) provide liquid, diversified real estate exposure without the hassles of direct property ownership.
